Thoughts on the Merits of Transport-Planning Packages
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> Transport-planning packages are increasingly being reappraised for technical content and role, in the current climate of capital rationing and short-run planning horizons. This paper outlines in a broad manner the major roles of established packages and suggests the major areas of deficiency, given that the present perceived planning emphasis will hold in the future. The important distinction between the concept of packages per se and the particular models used therein is emphasised. Particular reference is made to the improved Urban Transportation Planning System (UTPS) package of the US Department of Transportation (1977). </jats:p>

title: PLANNING AND PROGRESS CONTROL OF LARGER OFFSHORE PROJECTS
container-title: Proceedings of SPE European Petroleum Conference

title: Planning And Progress Control Of Larger Offshore Projects
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>The problem with offshore projects has been time delivery time. This has led to a conclusion that offshore projects are something special. They are not. The main object of this paper is to show that a successful control of both planning, progress and cost of a large offshore project can be obtained by simple and well known planning techniques.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Introduction</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>During the period 1973 and up till now Aker Group has built or completed 7 gravity structures + 2 jackets for the North Sea.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>These projects have all been in the range of 0,5 - 4 million man hours. Up till 1973 Aker Group was mainly a shipbuilding company. During our first projects (Beryl A and Brent B) we experienced that our projects (Beryl A and Brent B) we experienced that our existing planning technology was not suitable for offshore projects. This was mainly because our existing system was developed for products with a rather firm scope of work. Our new products for the oil industry, had to be constructed while they were developed and engineered.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>During the course of the projects we felt rather confused. Neither planning nor progress reporting were under control. The budgets followed the same trend.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Based on this experience, we had two choices:To develop or buy a new planning systemModify our existing system.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>We chose to do the latter.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>This paper describes our system. It is based on the following main parameters:It shall be simple and logicalIt shall suit both planning, progress control and cost controlIt shall be possible to use, both computerized and manually.It shall be hierarchal.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The system (and also this paper) is very simple. "Experts" have tried to mystify the planning and control technique. But the basic philosophy planning and control technique. But the basic philosophy of planning is always the same. One describes one piece of work to be done, and tries to estimate the piece of work to be done, and tries to estimate the manhours in that connection. If you do that for all activities, you have a plan for the whole project. The planning technique only describes how you arrange these activities.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>THEORY AND BASIC CRITERIAS</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>The planning procedures are developed for a project. For a contractor to the North Sea, this means to design, engineer and construct a structure, a plant or a platform. The project has a clear completion time (generally strict) and the total work is rather extensive from 300,000 to millions of manhours. The procedures shown here will be too complicated to involve in full, if a project is of small nature.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Aker uses EDP for many purposes. We have a complete EDP registration system for manhours.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>This enables us to sort all manhours invested in a project into different kind of parameters. They can be project into different kind of parameters. They can be sorted pr. trade, pr. subcontractor, pr. area etc. We also have totally computerized systems for planning, based on a CPM technique. With correct activity definitions, this enable us to sort planned activities into the same criterias.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>For material take-off and material control we use a combined computerized and manual system. When ordering and controlling purchase deliveries, we use computer systems, for the actual take-off of material pr. work order, we mostly do it manually. To save time for sorting of data in a larger project, computerized systems are a great advantage.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Another basic criteria for a planning and control system is that the project manager has authority and communication line to all parties involved in a project. Anybody, who performs actions which have an input to the progress, must report to the same system.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>P. 31</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

title: Use Of Reservoir Simulation Models In The Development Planning Of The Statfjord Field
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>This paper describes the application of reservoir simulation models in the development planning of Statfjord field. The techniques used in all completed Statfjord field studies are reviewed. The paper concentrates, however, on the geologic data, simulation methods, and results of the 1977 Full Field Development Study. This study is the largest and most comprehensive study presently completed. The studies which are currently underway are also reviewed briefly, but a comprehensive report of this work is beyond the scope of this paper.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>INTRODUCTION</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>The Statfjord Field is located on the border between Norway and the United Kingdom about 200 km northwest of the city of Bergen. Figure 1 shows its location in relation to other North Sea fields. The largest part of the field lies within the Norwegian Blocks 33/9 and 33/12 but a significant portion extends into United Kingdom Block 211/24.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The field was discovered in March 1974 by the Statoil-Mobil Group. operators for the Norwegian license 037. with their first wildcat Well 33/12-1. The discovery well encountered the Brent sand at 2382 m with an oil/water contact at 2584 m subsea. This contact has since been confirmed and is used as the field oil/water contact in the Brent sand. The well was located near the structural crest and produced oil which was undersaturated by approximately 1500 psi at the pressure datum depth of 2469 m. No gas cap was found and from the well location it was concluded that none existed in the reservoir. This has since been confirmed by other wells.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The confirmation well, 33/9-1, was drilled early in 1974. It encountered the Brent Formation with a full oil column and confirmed the productivity of the sand. The second major reservoir, the Statfjord, was discovered by the third well, 33/12-2, which found a partial Brent formation at 2458 m and the Statfjord Sand at approximately 2680 m with a full productive column. The Statfjord Sand oil/water contact was established at 2803 m subsea using the highest known water in Well 33/9-1 and lowest known oil in Well 33/12-2. As in the case of the Brent Reservoir, no gas cap was observed. The reservoir crude from the Well 33/12-2 tests was undersaturated by over 2700 psi at the datum depth of 2701 m and it was therefore concluded that the reservoir had no gas cap.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

title: Reservoir Development Planning For The Forties Field
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>The initial development plan and subsequent development of the Forties Field are compared. The paper shows how the geological model was modified by results of development drilling, and a reservoir description is included. A prediction of future performance is presented.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>DISCOVERY, INITIAL APPRAISAL AND CONCEPTUAL PLANS</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>Forties Field, located primarily in the U.K. Licence Block 21/10, is situated nearly 180 km ENE of Aberdeen (Figure 1). It was discovered in October 1970, when oil-bearing Palaeocene sandstones, (in what has subsequently been named the Forties Formation, Ref. 1) were encountered in an anticline at 2100m subsea. Four appraisal wells, drilled during 1971–1972, proved the existence of a major oilfield with an area of some 90 sq km and a first estimate STOOIP of 4600 million bbl.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Pre-development stratigraphical and structural knowledge of the field has already been published (Ref. 2 and 3). The Forties Formation can be split into two lithologically distinct sequences - an upper predominantly sandy sequence and a lower interbedded sandstone and shale sequence. These are now referred to as the Sandstone and Shale Members of the Forties Formation (Figure 2). The Sandstone Member contains most of the Forties oil.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>A model of sand distribution was constructed from available appraisal well and seismic data (Figure 3). Three significantly different areas of sandstone development were identified within the Field. These were:Central and Northern area - Very good reservoir characteristics and potential aquifer support.Western area - Good reservoir development, but subject to more variability.Southern and southeastern - Very poor sand development.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The reservoir rock and fluid data were quite favourable to oil production although the reservoir crude was highly undersaturated. The initial values of the more important parameters are listed below:</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Forties Field Reservoir and Fluid Properties</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Average Porosity 27% Average Water Saturation 23% Average Permeability 400 md Reservoir Pressure 3215 psig at 2175 mss Reservoir Temperature 195 °F at 2175 mss Saturation Pressure 1090 psig Oil Gravity GOR 37 ° API GOR 340 SCF/STB FVF 1.23 Formation Water Salinity 101,900 mg/l Oil Water Contact 2217 mss Thickest Oil Column 150 m gross Reservoir Oil Viscosity 0.8 cp</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Inspection of the initial data indicated that this inherently low-energy reservoir required some form of external energy, either in the form of natural water influx or fluid injection, or both, for optimum recovery of its reserves.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Conceptual Plans</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>During the period 1972–74, many studies were performed to assess the probable reservoir performance. Most of these involved computer simulation models with varying degrees of refinement. Included were both single phase and multiphase two and three-dimensional layered models. They were used to investigate pressure behaviour under various offtake profiles (centred around a 400 MBD plateau), movement of water vertically and horizontally and the effect of the wide range in permeabilities. A radial model checked the adequacy of peripheral water injection.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Forties Field Reservoir and Fluid Properties</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Average Porosity 27% Average Water Saturation 23% Average Permeability 400 md Reservoir Pressure 3215 psig at 2175 mss Reservoir Temperature 195 °F at 2175 mss Saturation Pressure 1090 psig Oil Gravity GOR 37 ° API GOR 340 SCF/STB FVF 1.23 Formation Water Salinity 101,900 mg/l Oil Water Contact 2217 mss Thickest Oil Column 150 m gross Reservoir Oil Viscosity 0.8 cp</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Inspection of the initial data indicated that this inherently low-energy reservoir required some form of external energy, either in the form of natural water influx or fluid injection, or both, for optimum recovery of its reserves.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Conceptual Plans</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>During the period 1972–74, many studies were performed to assess the probable reservoir performance. Most of these involved computer simulation models with varying degrees of refinement. Included were both single phase and multiphase two and three-dimensional layered models. They were used to investigate pressure behaviour under various offtake profiles (centred around a 400 MBD plateau), movement of water vertically and horizontally and the effect of the wide range in permeabilities. A radial model checked the adequacy of peripheral water injection.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

title: Planning and University Autonomy
Exploration Planning for Sandur Manganese Ores
items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Three prevailing ore types viz., stratiform, podiform and tabular deposits occur at the incidence ratio of 75:6:19. The stratiform orebodies can be designated as plenemensurate and regular; the podiform types as partimensurate and complicated; and the tabular ones as extramensurate and irregular.</jats:p>
               <jats:p>Based on the study presented here, a stratiform body may be explored on 100m × 100m square grid by core-drilling for the results to remain within the confidence level of ±20%; while pediform bodies may be explored with jack hammer-cum-diamond drilling at 50m × 50m square grid and the tabular deposits at 20 m × 20m square grid with deep pits-cum-drilling for the results to remain at the same level of assurance.</jats:p>

title: Murchison Project Preliminary Planning Organization
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>The Murchison Project is a North Sea field development project which formally commenced with budget approval in September, 1976 but in fact actually began in August, 1975 with the test program for the discovery well. This paper will describe the preliminary planning during the year up to project preliminary planning during the year up to project approval, a comprehensive effort which included:–Selecting the number and location of delineation wells.–Reserves estimates and productivity analysis.–Analysing development options, principally platform type, offtake method and use of subsea wells.–Preliminary design of platform and producing facilities.–Selecting design and project management contractors.–Estimating costs.–Planning and scheduling.–Economics, with emphasis on sensitivity and risk analysis.–Partner and government relationships.–Project management philosophy and organization, incorporating results of a study of earlier North Sea projects.–Obtaining project approval.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>The paper provides a check-list of the many things that must be done and one set of methods used to analyse, justify, and prepare to execute a major North Sea development project. It should be useful for others contemplating a very large offshore development project either in the North Sea or elsewhere.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>The paper presents preliminary results of the study at a stage approximately half-way through the scheduled project life. It is concluded that the overall planning effort was invaluable in "selling" the project and in getting the approved project off to a project and in getting the approved project off to a running start.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Introduction</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>North Sea oil exploitation required a new class of offshore development project for an unprecedented combination of harsh environmental design conditions and large-sized fields. Many of the early projects were launched in those euphoric times just before or after the 1973/74 oil embargo when oil prices were shooting up and security of crude supply had highest national priority. As a consequence of the haste with which priority. As a consequence of the haste with which these projects were undertaken and the period of rapid inflation in which they were built, most project schedules were extended a year or more and budgets overrun by factors of two to three.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>In terms of their primary goals, the early projects were successful. Oil is flowing, balances of projects were successful. Oil is flowing, balances of payments have been improved and project economics are payments have been improved and project economics are attractive. But the well-publicised slippages and overruns left a legacy of management scepticism on initial estimates and schedules that have brought about a ouch more deliberate approach to the "second generation" projects.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>This is a case history of the beginnings of the Murchison Project, one of the second-generation North Sea oil developments. It covers the period prior to actual project commencement, beginning with discovery in August, 1975 and ending with management approval to proceed with design and construction in September 1976.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>P. 7</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

title: Annual AIBS Meeting: Odum Urges Early Planning for Development in the South
Division of Chemical Education: American Chemical Society: Planning for the Future
Perceived Distance and Spatial Interaction
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> The paper seeks to test the proposition that manufacturers perceive the space within which they operate in behavioural, noneuclidean terms, in terms of ‘hierarchic’ distance, the distance between economic regions within a defined functional hierarchy, rather than in rational, euclidean, cost-distance terms. A hierarchic-distance metric is developed for New Zealand and this is used in an interaction model to predict the pattern of Auckland manufacturers' sales linkages, which are then compared with similar predictions generated from the same interaction model and a linear transportation model employing a cost-distance metric, and the results of all the models are compared with surveyed patterns of sales linkage. The use of the hierarchic metric is found to enhance the explanation of observed patterns of sales linkage, a finding which holds important implications for explanations of the location of economic activity in general. </jats:p>

title: Social Accounts, Social Indicators and Development Planning
Family allowance and family planning in Chile.
items.abstract: <jats:p> Family allowances designed to promote maternal and child health and welfare could be self-defeating if they stimulated otherwise unwanted births, as often assumed. That assumption, with its public health and demographic implications, needs testing. An attempt to test it was made in Chile in 1969--1970 through interviews with 945 wives receiving an allowance and 690 non-recipients. Recipients practiced contraception significantly more than did non-recipients. This was not explained by wives' educational attainment or employment, the couples' earnings, or number of living children, but was associated with a 50 per cent greater utilization of professional prenatal care by recipients during the most recent pregnancy; women with such care (regardless of allowance status) were 75 per cent more likely than others to control their fertility. Prenatal care was probably sought more by recipients in part because an additional stipend was provided as soon as pregnancy was confirmed, usually at clinics with integrated family planning. Greater family income, attributable to the allowance, probably also contributed to the recipients' better prenatal attention and to contraceptive practice. Noteworthy, too, was the finding that with the number of living children controlled, contraceptive practice was significantly greater amoung couples who had never lost a child. </jats:p>

title: Should Planning Agencies Allocate Managers Instead of Beds?
Evaluating And Planning Directional Wells Utilizing Post Analysis Techniques And A Three Dimensional Bottom Hole Assembly Program
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Detailed post-analysis can significantly reduce the cost of drilling complex and troublesome wells. It can lessen the learning curve for drilling in a particular area and assist in the training of inexperienced drilling personnel.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>Over the past three years, 72 directional wells have been post-analyzed in detail. Sixteen of these have been in the North Sea. From this work, a simple technique has evolved to post-analyze a well in such a manner that the complex interactions of the key variables are understood. These include: weight-on-bit, rotary speed, penetration rate, hole inclination and direction, geology, bits, and bottom hole assemblies. Post-analysis can be used to assess whether the trajectory changes were man induced or caused by the geology. This type of post-analysis does not require the use of a computer program.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>A computer program is necessary to analyze the complex behavior of the bottom hole assembly. A finite element algorithm was developed to do this. The program was designed to calculate the three-dimensional forces and displacements associated with any bottom hole assembly subjected to axial loading in a borehole. The borehole can either have a constant or variable inclination and direction. The program can be used to analyze bottom hole assemblies of wells that have been drilled (post-analysis) and/or help plan bottom hole assemblies in future wells.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>Further applications of the post-analysis technique is the evaluation of a trajectory change using a bent sub with a mud motor or by jetting with the pumps. A new useful method of evaluating the ideal performance of a mud motor correction run is presented with examples.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>A complete development of the post-analysis technique is presented. An interpretation of a typical directional well that has been post-analyzed is cited. Application of the computer program to evaluate some of the assemblies that were run in the example is covered. A new technique to analyze and plan deflection tool runs for any inclination angle is presented with examples.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Introduction</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>In 1972, a research project to optimize directional wells was initiated which required detailed drilling information. The normal drilling data was available from drilling recorder charts, bit and mud records, and tour sheets. However, detailed information on bottom hole assembly (BHA) configurations, dimensions and where the assemblies were run was virtually non-existant or not usable. Detailed data of weight-on-bit and rotary speed was also scarce. Forms specially designed for directional wells were drafted and sent out to the field for completion. Response was good. Within two years, detailed drilling data on more than 50 wells had been accumulated. Data was obtained from the Gulf of Mexico, Wyoming, Texas, Canada, Michigan, the North Sea, Trinidad, Iran and Holland.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>By 1974, the effort to understand the mechanism of directional drilling had not significantly progressed. Between 1972 and 1974 an approach was taken to physically observe the directional drilling operation and learn by experience, like a directional driller. The outcome was that the observer became an excellent directional driller, but a full understanding of the total mechanism of the variable's interaction was not learned.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>One of the major difficulties in interpreting trajectory behavior was the lack of being able to accurately analyze the bottom hole assembly behavior. To alleviate this deficiency, a computer program was developed that would calculate the three-dimensional displacements and forces for any type of bottom hole assembly. To do this a finite element algorithm was used.1</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The first round of post-analysis using the new program was very disappointing. Results in most part did not agree and in some cases were completely out of phase. However, it was this work that led to recognition of the importance of hole curvature on the bottom hole assembly response.2</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

Understanding Unbiased Dimensions: The Use of Repertory-Grid Methodology
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> The unbiased nature of the dimensions derived from multidimensional scaling poses a problem of interpretation. Subjective labelling by the researcher assumes that his judgments correspond to those of the respondents and is unsatisfactory. Identification of the dimensions needs to be based upon information gathered from the respondents themselves and in terms of the manner by which they were originally construed. Such information can be derived from the use of the repertory-grid test, which, like multidimensional scaling, requires subjects to make judgments of similarity between objects. The repertory-grid test also provides verbal labels for the distinctions that are made. A principal-components analysis of the repertory-grid data provides a number of components which are shown to be equivalent to the dimensions derived from multidimensional scaling. The use of component scores that relate to the verbal labels allows the dimensions to be identified in terms of the evaluations and perceptions of the respondents. </jats:p>

title: Interzonal Migration: Some Historical Tests of Spatial-Interaction Models
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> Observed migration and survival flows between counties and between standard regions are used to test alternative calibrations of a doubly constrained spatial-interaction model. Spatial variation in the propensity to migrate over distance is examined in an analysis of zone-specific decay parameters, and two methods of splitting aggregate migration flows according to reason for move are investigated. The results of the model tests for age/sex-disaggregated data underline regional variations in propensities to migrate and in mean distances migrated. </jats:p>

title: Gravity-Model Estimates and Exact Maximum-Entropy Solutions: Their Differences
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> The trip-distribution problem is discrete in formulation and combinatorial in nature. This truism has been ignored, as well as obscured, by the total attention focused on the use of the asymptotic methods of the gravity model for the maximum-entropy estimation of interzonal trips. These estimates appear to be reasonably reliable in indicating the regions—not the exact states—of highest probability. The Darwin–Fowler derivation of the gravity model demonstrates that the asymptotic solution is exactly equal to the average of all feasible microstates. Calibration of the model can be based on this proposition. An approach to testing the principle that all microstates are equally probable is outlined. </jats:p>

title: Political Aspects of Social Justice and Physical Planning in an Abstract City
items.abstract: <jats:p>This essay examines the issue of consistency between certain short‐run effects of urban policy and the corresponding incidence of policy. Short‐run effects are politically important in democracies because they determine popular support. Incidence, on the other hand, is socially important because it defines the level of welfare and its distribution among citizens. It is seen that the two are not necessarily consistent. Inconsistencies arise within both the social and the spatial realms of urban policy. Such inconsistencies depend upon individual preferences, urban morphology, urban technology, and upon the structure of society itself.</jats:p>

title: University of Illinois
Material Requirements Planning in a Noncomputerized Environment
items.abstract: <jats:p> This paper reviews briefly the material requirements planning (MRP) concept and shows how its major elements can assist a small manufacturer to control production and inventories for some products without the use of a computer. The prerequisite is an uncomplicated product consisting of few parts. To illustrate this, an actual application of MRP to the manufacture of greenhouses is described. </jats:p>

title: A Note on the Calibration of Maximum-Performance Spatial-Interaction Models
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> Evidence is presented to show that the improvement in model performance achieved by the family of maximum-performance spatial-interaction models developed by Openshaw and Connolly (1977) may be explicable solely for statistical reasons and that there is no need for a geographical or behavioural explanation, as was suggested. </jats:p>

title: Assessing Organizational Planning and Teamwork: An Action Research Methodology
container-title: The Journal of Applied Behavioral Science
items.abstract: <jats:p> Organizations often undertake planned change or OD interventions such as Management By Objectives (MBO) or team building without clearly identifying the current state of teamwork and planning among their own personnel. To overcome that deficiency, this article illustrates an approach for providing both quantitative and qualitative data regarding teamwork and planning. Utilization of such data concurrently with a "white paper" and OD survey feedback methodology is described. A case history of an actual intervention and sample data are provided. This approach is assessed using the theory bases of role perception accuracy and role compliance. The use of data from the methodology for providing feedback to individuals, dyads, and management teams as well as a baseline for considering planning or team-building approaches to OD is stressed. Methodological limitations are also considered. </jats:p>

title: Planning for effectiveness in the social services — an appraisal of the corporate approach
The National Regional Research Planning System: An Example from Rural Development
container-title: Journal of the Northeastern Agricultural Economics Council
items.abstract: <jats:p>Public decision makers generally and especially those in the executive branch of the Federal government are demanding increasing amounts of information on which to base research policy and budget decisions. Zero-based budgeting provides a mechanism for revealing the priorities of an organization in a very specific context. The Congress in more general terms is requesting advice on research priorities. Such developments as (1) the proposed cuts in formula grant funds (e.g., Hatch funds) and increases in competitive grant funds contained in FY 1979 executive budget for the USDA, (2) substantial critical testimony before Congressional committees by spokesmen for groups who believe they are underserved by the Land-Grant system (e.g., low income and minority groups), and (3) a possible tax revolt growing out of the recent California referendum, suggest that these demands for information are likely to increase rather than decrease.</jats:p>

title: On the Existence of Optimal Paths and Cost Surfaces in Isotropic Continuous Transportation Models
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> In continuous transportation models, minimum-cost paths are obtained by variational methods, in analogy with geometrical optics. Previous contributions on this subject have stated the appropriate Euler equations and discussed the possibility of defining a transportation-cost surface on which optimal paths are geodesics. The present paper discusses the sufficiency conditions for optimal paths and the existence conditions for cost surfaces, in terms of Gaussian theory. It is also demonstrated that, when the transportation model is isotropic, the cost surface is conformal to the plane. </jats:p>

Effects of Research Priorities the Northeast Marketing and Competition Research Planning Steering Committee
container-title: Journal of the Northeastern Agricultural Economics Council
items.abstract: <jats:p>The Research Program Steering Committee on Marketing and Competition was created in 1977 by the Northeast Experiment Station Directors. It was one of ten such committees asked to develop a master research program to identify research areas of high priority, coordinate and consolidate current research programs, implement new approaches, and coordinate future research plans. This particular committee was asked to cover research programs in “Marketing and Competition” (RP 6.03). The Master Program, still in the development stage, is an indicative plan. It is designed to indicate needed areas of research and priorities and suggests a mechanism for encouraging the allocation of resources in the indicated directions. The effect on research priorities will depend on how well we did our job, on how seriously the limited number of involved researchers take our suggestions, and on the impact we all have on the allocation of funds and human resources.</jats:p>

Cumulative Stress and Cumulative Inertia: A Behavioral Model of the Decision to Move
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> A model of the probability of moving which incorporates aspects of the independent-trials process, the stage in the life cycle, and the concept of cumulative inertia is formulated. The model is based on the interaction of two forces. On the one hand there is a certain resistance to moving (cumulative inertia) and on the other the household may be dissatisfied with certain attributes of the present dwelling and its surroundings (residential stress). The probability of moving is a function of the resultant of these two conflicting forces. The model is designed not only to predict who will move (those individuals with high residential stress relative to their resistance to moving), but also to predict how an individual's probability of moving is likely to change over time. Some simple and limited simulations suggest that the model will capture rather well the different kinds of mobility rates which are observed from empirical data sets. </jats:p>

Naturally, the planning for relief actions diifers in some respects according to whether it is related to natural disasters or to armed conflicts. However, there are important common elements in this planning which merit development and joint study by the ICRC and the League.</jats:p>

title: Towards a More Rational Consideration of Census Areal Units: Daily Urban Systems in Britain
container-title: Environment and Planning A: Economy and Space
items.abstract: <jats:p> The utility of data based on areal units, such as British censuses, depends at least as much on the definition of these areal units as on the variables measured. The discontinuation of the local-authority areas used for all previous censuses allows a radical evaluation of the alternative areas for census-data presentation. A conceptual basis is discussed which contrasts simple areal aggregates with genuine ‘objects of interest’. It is suggested that the daily urban system is the candidate which best meets these criteria for a meaningful areal unit for census-data presentation. </jats:p>

title: PLANNING FOR BETTER STANDARDS IN THE CARE OF THE NEUROLOGICAL SEQUELAE OF TRAUMA
container-title: Australian and New Zealand Journal of Surgery
items.abstract: <jats:p>Injuries of the nervous system are common, and cause many deaths and much permanent disability. They inflict an enormous financial burden on the national economy; in Australia, adequate data are at present lacking, but a simple extrapolation from Canadian statistics suggests an estimate of more than $500,000,000 annually for the injuries resulting from road traffic accidents alone; if other causes of injury are included, the figure may reach one billion dollars.</jats:p><jats:p>The neurosurgeon is specifically trained to undertake the management of all forms of neurological trauma; however, in Australia, and in many other countries, only a small minority of such injuries receive neurosurgical care. This is chiefly because the number of neurosurgeons at present available is small in relation to the tasks. Many cases must therefore be in the care of general or orthopaedic surgeons, especially in country centres, and it is important that these surgeons should have some basic neurosurgical training. The Neurosurgical Society of Australasia wishes to formulate a programme to ensure that opportunities for such training are available throughout Australia. This programme should also embody a national plan for research into the treatment and prevention of neurological trauma.</jats:p>
